ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: how to conduct an actual application of everything I have learned

Congenital heart defects, especially single-ventricle. Fontan procedure: how it was developed, how it works anatomically, research in improving it. Looked at the problem of solving congenital single ventricle heart defects from many angles: anatomical, mechanobiological, computational, experimental, economical, and so on. Worked on a group project on an 'outside the box' solution culminating in a presentation and paper. It was very interesting to learn about this field about which I knew nothing as a non-biology-major.
Fluid flow for biological problems, a mix of biology, engineering, and mathematical modeling applied to the study of single ventricle disorder.
I learned about heart and healthy vs. pathological function. This class also covered tissue engineering and applications in congenital heart disease patients.
Amazing course! Highly recommend if interested in learning about the intersection of biomedical engineering and biology.
Basic information about congenital heart disease, mechanobiology, the immune system, statistical and computational methods, fluid dynamics

During our final presentations, a doctor sitting in on the class that day remarked how surprised they were that we knew so much about the field. I learned about congenital heart diseases and everything one needs to know to understand the field of mechanobiology. My favorite piece of knowledge is forever remembering the structure and functions of the heart.
Scientific paper writing, real-world application of scientific principles, out of the box brainstorming

Very good understanding of the problem in congenital heart defects, and current solutions / procedures. Past approaches and how they have evolved. Viewed congenital heart disease through many lenses. Developed skills in searching for, reading, and writing research papers.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: great class, could chill out at end of the semester

Strength: Prof. Humphrey is extremely knowledgeable and passionate about the subject. Interesting and engaging lectures about a broad range of topics. Got to see lots of aspects of the problem on a surface level. Very accessible for any major; different parts will be challenging depending on your background. I knew nothing about this before and now I know a good amount.
Weakness: Assignments were arbitrary/unscheduled/random. Not always clear what we needed to know for the exams. Due to time/scope could not go super deep in any one topic.

Strengths: Professor Humphrey was a great and engaging lecturer
Weaknesses: Group projects always suffer from the problem that some people pull their weight more than others

This course is designed to spark students' interest in something that can be fixed/improved about research/engineering/medicine related to tissue engineering. Professor Humphrey does a really good job with this. Most of the class is organized around a group project that builds off of the material taught in the first half of the course. As such, the second half of the course is mostly group project work, and there was very little material between the midterm and the final. Considering the group project requires a presentation and a paper due at the end of the semester, the final exam seemed like an unnecessary addition. It wasn't much different than the midterm, and we had already plenty of grades (10 homework assignments, a midterm, final presentation and final paper).
Course is well organized!

Strengths: lectures are very interesting, the group aspect of the course was nice
Weaknesses: some concepts difficult to learn and find outside, supplementary material about, lack of practice for concepts/delayed feedback on homeworks

Strengths: Professor Humphrey makes each lecture deeply engaging. Everything is done on blackboard, and the pace is manageable and makes time for questions and tangents. This course reminded me a lot of my favorite high school science classes in that you don't need a background in biology to be able to deeply engage each day and ask more about the subject. Assignments are light, and the final project is reasonable. Weaknesses: not too many. The final was a little more difficult than expected

Strengths: wonderful and engaging teacher
Weaknesses: if you don't take notes religiously you cannot do this course

Uncertainty with grading. I wish our grade was structured more into check-ins i.e. we would turn in a proposal, receive a grade that would count towards the final paper category, and get concrete feedback. This would alleviate some of the uncertainty among the grading. I also think an in-class second midterm instead of a final, and a faster turnaround for presentation grades would have been useful.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: yes, if you are bme and are looking to actually apply skills
Yes! It was very interesting! Accessible to any major, though different parts will be hard depending on your background.
Yes!
I would recommend this course to any student interested in engineering or research.
Yes! Professor Humphrey is one of the best Yale Professors. This class teaches valuable real world material that is used in everyday biomedical engineering and medical applications.
Yes! Really interesting course that isnt just a regular lecture. Professor truly cares about his students and a great way to work with peers across various fields

Absolutely. I took this for my science credit and greatly enjoyed it. I found the professor and the topic deeply engaging. The class was ~30 people and yet felt closer to a seminar than a leminar/lecture. Professor Humphrey learned all our names. Just a small heads up that there is some amount of algebra and partial differential equations that come up in the mechanics discussions and on midterm/test questions.
Absolutely. Forwarning, however, there is little work outside class for most of the school year. 90% of the work takes place in the last couple of weeks. There is a paper, presentation, and final.

Yes- This class was amazing, largely due to Professor Humphrey constantly encouraging everyone and maintaining an overwhelmingly positive attitude every day.
I will say that one thing that felt problematic to me was that 75% of the final grade was unknown at the deadline for Cr/D/Fail. This is because of ungraded homework assignments, a final presentation, the final exam, and a final paper.
If you take this course, I would also advise getting started on the final project early, and meeting with your group outside of class time early-on. Professor Humphrey is always willing to provide advice and guidance along the way.
Also, even though other reviews mentioned an interdisciplinary approaches/projects, I think it is far overstated the course is at heart a biomedical research course. I dont think any of the projects this year had any large non-biology component, but more of a we could use computational modeling and artificial intelligence to improve our approach in the future or a brief economic assessment of the market for something like a bioreactor.
